utterance: Annika Barber: Yeah, so certainly humans are pretty decoupled from the circadian environment in the modern world. Um, so we're we're really interested in considering time as a variable and in a circadian system, the clock in your brain synchronizes to the external environment, but you also have molecular clocks in every other tissue, um, including in your gut and in your liver, um, and in other metabolic tissues. And what's fascinating is that the clock in the brain can really only be reset by light inputs, but clocks in peripheral tissues can be reset by all kinds of additional cues.

annotations.develop idea: The speaker expands on existing knowledge about the circadian system, its synchronization with environmental cues, and its effects on different bodily tissues.
annotations.signal expertise: The speaker explicitly demonstrates her expertise in chronobiology, discussing her research focus and specific aspects of circadian rhythms.

utterance: Annika Barber: And what this can lead to is circadian desynchrony where basically different tissues tell different times. So in an ideally entrained organism, the circadian clock, the circadian molecular transcriptional translational feedback loop is telling the same time in every different organ system. So all of the organ systems are temporarily coordinated with each other. But if you do things like eat in the middle of the night, drink caffeine, use drugs of abuse, use pharmaceutical drugs, um, you know, eliminate your microbiome, take antibiotics, um, you can provide these new entrainment cues for your gut.

annotations.develop idea: Annika Barber is expanding on her previous idea about the circadian system, discussing circadian desynchrony and its implications.
annotations.None: No other codes seem to directly apply to this utterance as it primarily involves elaboration on an existing idea rather than proposing a new one, asking a question, or other listed activities.

utterance: Annika Barber: Um, and that can basically reset the clock in your gut and reset the clock in your liver, um, and basically entrain it against the brain clock. And we do know that when you got this like long term decoupling of circadian clocks between organ systems, especially between the brain and metabolic organ systems, you can get metabolic syndrome, you can get weight gain, um, and so, and then you can get, you know, the more obvious circadian disruptions of things like sleep disturbance, which can also then feed back to just continuing to decouple circadian systems further. Um, so one of the things that that my lab is interested in doing is trying to understand interactions between um aging, food timing, um, and behavior using drosophila because we can manipulate their genetics and their environment so easily for large cohorts of flies.

annotations.develop idea: The speaker expands on existing ideas about circadian rhythms, their disruption, and potential health impacts, and discusses her lab's research interests in this area.

utterance: Annika Barber: Um, we don't want to kill them. Um, we're aiming for about a 50% survival at 30 days. annotations.develop idea: The speaker is expanding on their research idea, providing details on methods and expected outcomes.

annotations.ask question: Irene Yang is requesting information or clarification from Annika Barber on a prior statement regarding the relationship between circadian rhythms and dietary patterns.

utterance: Annika Barber: Um, so we're that's something that I'm really intrigued by. So I in my postdoc lab I focused on circadian rhythms of locomotor behavior. And in flies, um they're what are called crepuscular. So they're most active at dawn and dusk. Um, and their locomotor behavior is very similar across background strains of flies. They all have a peak of activity in the morning and a peak of activity in the evening. Um, and I got really interested in investigating feeding rhythms, which is something newer in flies because we haven't really had the resolution to look at single fly feeding until more recently. Um, and so when I started to look at feeding, I thought that their feeding patterns would follow their locomotor activity, that they would eat the most when they were walking up, walking around, being awake the most. Um, and I thought that when I looked at classic circadian locomotor rhythm mutants that I would see the same deficits in their feeding rhythms. And what I found is that for flies, um locomotor activity and feeding rhythms are very decoupled.

annotations.develop idea: The speaker is expanding on her research interests and findings, providing details about her study on circadian rhythms and feeding patterns in flies.

utterance: Annika Barber: Um, and to answer Jody's questions from the chat. Um, so humans are pretty terrible about how many hours a day they intake food. Um, actually, um, a couple of studies that have, well, they looked at largely undergraduate and graduate student populations. So I'm not sure how representative their food intake patterns are, probably amongst the worst, but um, they had they had students that wore um like essentially fitbits and then there was a button on their fitbit that they could press every time they put food in their mouth. So it was it was a really like they weren't trying to get them to log every meal. It was just like when you start eating press the button, when you stop eating press the button again. Um, and they found that on average in a cohort of thousands of students, people were eating 14 to 16 hours a day. Um, and um, so like between their first meal and their last meal, they were eating up to about 16 out of 24 hours. Um, and there's quite a lot of data that shows that restricting your feeding window to 10 hours or less per day is very beneficial for your health. Um, and so, you know, 16 hours is a pretty pretty broad window. Um, and and outside of the window of what most animals would eat um that are not humans. But most animals don't have insomnia cookies. Um, and they deliver till till 2:00 a.m. you guys. Just want you to know.

And so the question that I've always sort of ponder in the back of my head is how do we control for these metabolic variances that are occurring dynamically within the host? And how do we start to separate out signal from noise and what do we actually then start to comprise and assign significance to? utterance: JP Yu (Wisconsin) (he/him): So, you know what's really so there are like there are methodological templates to do this, you know, in a very high throughput fashion. So, you know, ostensibly what you could do is you can take human derived IPSCs, derive them into say neurons. And then you can put them into a very well described, well characterized like microfluidic system and you can just pulse through and do this massively parallel and measure all the analytes, all of the outcomes for that. The big question though is then somebody in study section is going to say, well that is not an accurate representation of the human brain or a vertebrate brain because how do you account for neuroal interactions? How do you account for synaptic interactions? How do you start to account for, you know, this new idea that it's not just chemical synapses, it's electrical synapses. So how do you recapitulate those very complex network interactions? So then you're stuck having to do this in an actual model. Mice are expensive, housing is expensive. You know, you can do it for like 20, but then when you start thinking about I need to do this for a thousands, that gets really, really crazy, really, really fast. Um, hey, so this is like the common, you know, this is the frustration and the the roadblock that I've come up against is, you know, we need to very at the very bare minimum start to describe some of these things at a foundational level. Then I write that exact grant to the NH and they say like, well we're not interested in description, we want a mechanism. And you're like, you show me a mechanism. There's no way to do this unless we actually even understand what it looks like to start with. So to me that's the the common tension with a lot of this, especially, you know, as a physician scientist, my my whole idea is I want to translate this. Like how do we help people? Um, don't get me wrong, I love the fundamental stuff. I'll I'll dig in the sandbox with all of y'all, but um, ultimately, how do we translate this into clinical populations?
